è¿™è¾¹çš„å»ºè®®æ˜¯ï¼Œä½œä¸ºä¸ªäººï¼Œæˆ‘å¹¶ä¸æ¨èå°†æ­¤æ–¹æ³•è¿ç”¨äºä¸ªäººåšå®¢ã€‚åŸå› å¾ˆç®€å•ï¼Œä½ åšå®¢ä¸€æ¬¡èƒ½æœ‰å‡ å¼ å›¾ç‰‡ï¼Ÿå¦‚æœä½ æ˜¯å¼€å›¾ç«™çš„ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè¿™ä¸ªæ–¹æ³•åˆšå¥½å¯ä»¥è¿ç”¨åˆ°ä½ çš„ç½‘ç«™é‡Œï¼Œåªè¦è¿›è¡Œå¤šåŸŸååˆ†å¼€å¹¶dnsæ¬²è§£æå°±å¯ä»¥è¿›ä¸€æ­¥æå‡ç½‘ç«™ä½“éªŒäº†ã€‚

æœ€åä¸Šç”Ÿè‚‰ï¼š

DNS prefetching is an attempt to resolve domain names before a user tries to follow a link. This is done using the computerâ€™s normal DNS resolution mechanism; no connection to Google is used. Once a domain name has been resolved, if the user does navigate to that domain, there will be no effective delay due to DNS resolution time. The most obvious example where DNS prefetching can help is when a user is looking at a page with many links to various domains, such as a search results page. When we encounter hyperlinks in pages, we extract the domain name from each one and resolving each domain to an IP address. All this work is done in parallel with the userâ€™s reading of the page, using minimal CPU and network resources. When a user clicks on any of these pre-resolved names, they will on average save about 200 milliseconds in their navigation (assuming the user hadnâ€™t already visited the domain recently). More importantly than the average savings, users wonâ€™t tend to experience the â€œworst caseâ€ delays for DNS resolution, which are regularly over 1 second.
